sections.transcript:
Section 1

Receptionist: Hi there the High Light Hair Salon here – how can I help you?
Customer: My name’s Amanda and I’d like to book an appointment please, with Susie – for as soon as possible. Just for a haircut, thanks.
Receptionist: That’s fine, Amanda just bear with me for a few seconds, I’m just going into Susie’s diary on the computer..... Okay, now we do have a free slot this afternoon at (Q1) 3.30 – she’s had a customer cancel this morning you see, would that be convenient?
Customer: Erm, no.... sorry, I wouldn’t be able to get there on time. How about around 5.30? You are open late this evening, aren’t you?
Receptionist: No... not any more, we close at 5.30 this evening – we used to stay open late three evenings a week, but we’ve cut that down now to just (Q2) Thursdays and Fridays, we haven’t opened late on Wednesdays since June. I can do you 5.30... ah no sorry, wait a minute... (Q3) 5.45 on Thursday if you like?
Customer: Yes that sounds great. I’ll book that please. Actually I only need a haircut for now, but I’d also like to talk with Susie about some suggestions for a hairstyle for my wedding... (Q4) I’m getting married in September and I’d like some advice...
Receptionist: Great. I’ll just take your full name and contact details. Susie will be happy to advise you Amanda. If you’ve got any ideas bring (Q5) some pictures in with you and she’ll be able to tell you what she thinks. Later on we can book some more appointments for you so you can try out some of the styles. Does that sound good?
Customer: Perfect!
Receptionist: So you’ve obviously been here before, if you know Susie....? What’s your surname please?
Customer: Actually, no I haven’t. A friend of mine, Jayne Sands, comes to you regularly and she (Q6) recommended Susie to me. She said that Susie’s just brilliant. My surname is Birns – Amanda Birns.
Receptionist: Burns? Is that B-U-R-N-S.
Customer: No, actually it’s (Q7) B –I –R-N-S. It’s spelt with an I not U.... And my contact number is... actually I’ll give you my work number as my mobile isn’t working properly and I’ve just moved to a new apartment and don’t have a landline yet.  So my work number is (Q8) 07 342 9001..
Receptionist: 07 342 9001... Okay. So we’ll look forward to seeing you on Thursday. Do you know how to find us? We’re at Eastgate (Q9/Q10) Shopping Centre.
Customer: Yes I remember seeing your shop a while ago.... you’re next door to the big electrical shop aren’t you?
Receptionist: That’s right, we used to be but the electrical shop isn’t here any more – it’s a big (Q9/Q10) pharmacy now. There’s open parking air parking to the rear of our building. Or you can park in the multi-storey car park in the centre. It’s free for the first three hours at both of the carparks, after that you pay on the meters..
Customer: Great, that’s good to know. Well thank you very much for your help – I’ll see you later in the week.  Bye for now......

Section 2 Good evening. My name is Dr James Philipps, and I have been invited here today to discuss my research and to tell you a little more about my new book, Silver Lining, which has just been published by Longman Press. This book covers one of my biggest interests – whether there are in fact aliens from other planets that have visited Earth in unidentified flying objects, or UFOs as they are more commonly known. I’d like to start with a quick introduction – over the last 12 years I have become increasingly interested in the subject of UFOs, and this book is a compilation of all the alien sightings I have heard about. Now, I understand that many people doubt whether visitors from other planets even exist, and I admit that until I did a lot of extensive research, I had my doubts, but I am now convinced that there is life on other planets and that aliens have indeed come to our planet. The television and the media has given us all a mental picture of an alien space craft - a silver ship with bright lights that moves at very high speed. However, what I was somewhat shocked to discover was that in all the eyewitness accounts I heard, people gave very precise and detailed descriptions that varied only slightly. Reports from America, Europe, Asia -  in fact, all over the world - share a significant number of similarities. Now, my aim in writing this book was to gather together all the information available and make a kind of reference guide. There are statements from a vast number of different people, ranging from ordinary citizens to people quite high up in the government, accompanied with a lot of photographs and other evidence. I have deliberately avoided any personal opinions or interpretations, and as such the book is not presenting a subjective point of view, but the facts as they are currently known. Many people have drawn attention to the fact that the majority of UFO sightings have occurred in America, and I think that is something I should talk about. The popularity of science fiction programs in America could lead you to suspect that these sightings are nothing more than an overactive imagination. However, I have found there are a number of other factors that determine UFO sightings. In northern Europe, the number of reports is very low, whereas in southern Europe, where there is more open space, less light pollution and generally clearer skies, the number of sightings increases. Now when you consider the vast open areas of America, there is an argument that UFOs are simply easier to see in certain geographical and climatic situations .
My book also talks about a place in America which has often been in the media, commonly referred to as Area 51 and is in fact a military base in New Mexico. In 1947, this previously relatively unknown base became internationally famous when a man called MacBrazel - that's spelt MACBRAZEL - claimed to have found pieces of an alien spacecraft on his farm in Roswell. Now many people believe that this was true and that the government of the time took the debris to a secure location. Academics and government officials have claimed that what MacBrazel actually saw were pieces of a high-altitude weather balloon that had disintegrated. Unfortunately, the lack of information combined with the large number of possible alternate theories means, that no useful scientific conclusion can be drawn. Many people have asked me if I discuss the question of alien abduction in my book and I should tell you know that I don't really cover that. You see I was looking to present facts from which people could draw their own conclusions, but with these reported abductions, I found them to be very real unreliable. The final chapter of my book deals with some of the many scientific theories that could be argued support the idea that we have already been visited by aliens. The Great Pyramids of Egpyt, Stonehenge in the UK and many other archaeological areas certainly raise questions, but perhaps the most interesting new development has come from Scotland, where some recently discovered cave paintings show images very close to those described by eye witnesses in recent years. Well thank you very much for your time. Before we finish, I would just like to add that my books is available at all leading book stores priced at £19.99.

Section 3
Student 1: So how are you doing with your assignment for Marketing?
Student 2: Yeah not too badly, almost finished – it’s actually been really interesting, I’ve learned a lot.
Student 1: Cool! What research topic did you choose?
Student 2: Erm.... dealing with customers and how personalities and behaviour of customers and customer service representatives affects a company’s ability to meet their clients’ needs. It’s a report and needs to be a minimum of (Q21) 3000 words.
Student 1: Oh yeah, so how much have you finished now? I’ve written (Q22) about two thirds of mine – did I tell you my topic? It’s about product placement, you know, how stores might be designed to encourage people to spend more – interesting too!
Student 2: Yeah I’ve done about the same, 1/3 to go!
Student 1: Yeah me too - we’re a few days away from the deadline yet so I think I can do a pretty good job! So where did you find your research materials?
Student 2: There was quite a bit available in the university library actually, but I also found most of my research journals through (Q23) the online library. It’s a brilliant source of information.
Student 2: I’ve been looking into the common classification of behaviour into the 4 main behavioural types.
Student 1: Ah yes, I remember that from our lectures... it’s passive, aggressive, assertive... oh and what’s the other one. I can’t think now of the 4th one...
Student 2: Well, passive-aggressive like the name suggests is a kind of a mix of the two behaviours passive and then aggressive.
Student 1: How does that work then?
Student 2: Well, do you remember that we learned that probably of all the behaviours the most productive way to be is assertive – this means that you don’t let people just do what they want to if it has a negative effect, but that you’re able to put across your point of view effectively, (Q24) calmly and consider other people too.
Student 1: Yes that’s right.... and if I remember correctly we talked about how sometimes people confuse aggression with (Q25) assertiveness.
Student 2: Yeah, so while an aggressive person might not just let other people do what they like, they might talk angrily, be too bossy and be (Q26) inconsiderate of other people’s feelings.
Student 1: Right, so how does that translate into passive aggressive behaviour then? A passive person is quite the opposite of that aren’t they? I mean, they wouldn’t react or get angry or maybe say anything at all about a situation they are not happy with.
Student 2: That’s true, well a passive-aggressive personality might not say anything directly to others and would want to avoid (Q27) confrontation probably, but behind the scenes or indirectly they might say angry things or act aggressively. Talking behind someone’s back is an example of a passive aggressive trait.
Student 1: Right and so you are looking at all of this in the context of customer service? I have to say if a customer acted aggressively towards me I would find it hard not to be the same with them!
Student 2: Yeah, but the outcome wouldn’t be very positive! There’s a lot of skills that customer service representatives can use if someone is behaving angrily. A really good one I was reading about was to keep using the person’s name – you know, calmly and politely, the theory being that (Q28/29/30) it is more difficult for a person to treat another person rudely if the conversation is more personalised.
Student 1: Psychology is interesting isn’t it? I remember our lecturer saying that often (Q28/29/30) if a customer feels they are being listened to and respected that they are more likely to feel that they have had a good experience with a company – even if they didn’t actually get the product that they wanted. Being given something by someone who has poor customer service skills can be more irritating than being told politely that you’ll have to come back the next day!
Student 2: (Q28/29/30) Giving clients choices is a useful approach too. You know if you have a complaint about a faulty product and there are none in stock you might ask if they would like a refund or would prefer to wait for a replacement. Giving people choices gives them a feeling of worth and control and reduces the likelihood of them becoming irritable with the wait for the replacement.
Student 1: True, very true. Well I’m going to the library to work on my assignment this afternoon.... why don’t you come with me?
Student 2: Okay, let’s go now. And I am really looking forward to relaxing at the party on Saturday once we’ve handed everything in...

Section 4 Norfolk island is a small island in the Pacific Ocean which lies between Australia, New Zealand and New Caledonia. Norfolk Island and two neighbouring islands – Phillip Island and Nepean Island which form one of Australia’s external territories. (Q31) Although a territory of Australia, Norfolk island has its own flag, on which can be seen a green pine tree – this being representative of an evergreen tree native to Norfolk island itself. (Q32) Today, the island is the only non-mainland Australian territory to have achieved self-governance. The island is subject to separate immigration controls to the rest of Australia and (Q33) a certain amount of controversy surrounds its territory status to this day – some islanders insisting that in fact the island had been granted independence by Queen Victoria in the 1800s. Before the Europeans arrived, Norfolk Island was first settled by East Polynesian seafarers either from the Kermadec Islands north of New Zealand or from the North Island of New Zealand. They arrived in the (Q34) fourteenth or fifteenth century, and inhabited the island for several generations before they disappeared – to this day the reasons for their demise remain a mystery. Captain James Cook, was the first European to sight the island which he did in 1774, on his second voyage to the South Pacific on HMS Resolution. (Q35) The abundance of trees – as depicted on the island’s flag -was one of the major points of interest to be discovered by Northern Hemisphere explorers. Cook christened the island in honour of the (Q36) Duchess of Norfolk back in the UK – as it turned out, one year after the Duchess had actually died; since Cook had set out from England in 1772, he was unaware of her death which had already occurred in May 1773. On Tuesday 11 October 1774, for the first time, Cook went on shore to Norfolk Island and is said to have been impressed with the tall straight trees and New Zealand flax plants. He took samples back to the United Kingdom and reported on their potential uses for the Royal Navy. At that time, finding new sources of flax – which was used for ship sails and timber for ship masts – was crucially important to allow the United Kingdom to continue its control of ocean going activities. Captain Cook reported that (Q37) Norfolk Island had the second most plentiful supply of wood and mast timber in the south seas after New Zealand. What made Norfolk island a particularly attractive prospect to the British in conjunction with its plentiful supply of trees and flax was its lack of a (Q38) native population; there was therefore no one present to oppose colonisation unlike in New Zealand where opposition was a certainty from the native Maori population. Since however, the island was so small, (it has an area of 34.6 km2) the decision was taken for a dual colonization alongside New South Wales – the connection to Australia being therefore established. Today, most Islanders are of either European-only or combined European-Tahitian ancestry, being descendants of the Bounty mutineers as well as more recent arrivals from Australia and New Zealand.(Q39) About half of the islanders can trace their roots back to Pitcairn Island. The population of Norfolk Island was estimated in July 2003 to be 1,853, 20.2% of the population were 14 years and under, 63.9% were 15 to 64 years and 15.9% were 65 years and over. Islanders speak both English and a creole language known as Norfuk, which is in essence a blend of 1700s English and Tahitian. The Norfuk language is decreasing in popularity as more tourists travel to the island and more young people leave for work and study reasons; however, there are efforts to keep it alive through published dictionaries and the renaming of some tourist attractions to their Norfuk equivalents. Emigration is growing as many Islanders choose to move to Australia or New Zealand. There is only one school on the island which provides education to Australian Year 12. However, any student wishing to go on to university or another form of tertiary study must travel overseas as no such institutions exist on the island. (Q40) Many skilled workers now also elect to move overseas to pursue increased economic opportunities in bigger centres. Nowadays, the main economy of the island is tourism and a ban on the import of fruit and vegetables helps to ensure that agriculture remains fairly robust.
